<ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">Synthesis of La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>17H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1). A mixture of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.21<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), LaCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (792<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 2.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), KCl (130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1.75<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and water (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was sealed in a 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel after adjustment of the pH to 5 with 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M KOH. The mixture was heated at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>hours, followed by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C hour<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>. Dark green crystals were obtained (210<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, yield 60%).</ce:simple-para>
['solvothermal_synthesis', 'pH_adjustment']

<ce:section-title id="st035">Preparation of {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(Hdatrz)(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">A mixture containing Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (58.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Hdatrz (19.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ip (36.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in mixed H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O–CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (v:v<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1:1, 10.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) solution, and the initial pH value of the reactant mixture was adjusted to 6 by triethylamine. The resulting mixture was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (23.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and heated at 165<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h under autogenous pressure. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, red block-shaped crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly, washed with water and dried in air (Yield: 50%, based on NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ip). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>: C, 37.01; H, 2.76; N, 16.78. Found: C, 37.04; H, 2.65; N, 16.72%. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3409 (br), 3319 (w), 3167 (w), 1625 (s), 1588 (s), 1559 (s), 1481 (s), 1449 (s), 1386 (s), 1322 (w), 1011 (m), 985 (m), 952 (w), 797 (w), 778 (w), 724 (w), 666 (w).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st040">Preparation of [Co(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)(Hdatrz)(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">A mixture of Hdatrz (19.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ip (36.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and Co(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (24.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in mixed H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O–CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (v:v<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1:1, 10.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) solution, and the initial pH value of the reactant mixture was adjusted to <ce:italic>ca</ce:italic>. 6 by slow addition of triethylamine with constant stirring. The resulting mixture was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (23.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and heated at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h under autogenous pressure. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, red block-shaped crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly, washed with water and dried in air (Yield: 50%, based on Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> salt). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>CoN<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>: C, 39.14; H, 4.11; N, 19.02. Found: C, 39.14; H, 4.12; N, 19.05%. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3445 (s), 3333 (w), 3070 (w), 1670 (s), 1633 (s), 1546 (s), 1439 (s), 1370 (s), 1246 (w), 1083 (m), 1032 (m), 817 (w), 783 (m), 751 (w), 723 (m).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st045">Preparation of {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip)]·2.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">A mixture of Hdatrz (19.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ip (18.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (23.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in mixed H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O–C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH (v:v<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3:7, 10.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) solution, and the initial pH of the reactant mixture was adjusted to <ce:italic>ca</ce:italic>. 7 by slow addition of triethylamine with constant stirring. The resulting mixture was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (23.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and heated at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h under autogenous pressure. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, blue block-shaped crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly, washed with water and dried in air (Yield: 40%, based on Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> salt). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6.5</ce:inf>: C, 29.06; H, 3.56; N, 26.07. Found: C, 29.04; H, 3.53; N, 26.10%. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3446 (br), 3349 (w), 3244 (w), 1622 (s), 1582 (s), 1517 (s), 1380 (s), 1144 (w), 1107 (w), 1044 (w), 803 (w), 776 (m), 735 (m).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st050">Preparation of {[Co(datrz)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">A mixture of Hdatrz (9.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ip (21.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (14.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in doubly distilled water (15.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), and the initial pH of the reactant mixture was adjusted to <ce:italic>ca</ce:italic>. 6 by slow addition of triethylamine with constant stirring. The resulting mixture was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (23.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and heated at 140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h under autogenous pressure. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 3.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, pink block-shaped crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly, washed with water and dried in air (Yield: 50%, based on Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> salt). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>: C, 31.27; H, 2.36; N, 21.88. Found: C, 31.25; H, 2.37; N, 21.86%. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3422 (br), 3336 (w), 3270 (w), 3083 (w), 1620 (s), 1571 (s), 1533 (s), 1366 (s), 1348 (s), 1200 (w), 1102 (w), 1068 (w), 822 (w), 785 (w), 753 (w), 735 (m), 718 (s), 669 (w), 563 (w), 525 (w), 477 (w), 433 (w).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Preparations of the compounds</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The compound [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(azpy)(dmf)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6DMF (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) was prepared by diffusion of a DMF solution (200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>oba (5.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and azpy (6.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) into a DMF solution (200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of Zn(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (2.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol). Red columnar crystals were formed within a period of one week, and these were collected by filtration under a nitrogen atmosphere because of the highly moisture sensitivity. Elemental Anal. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">44</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">62</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> ([Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(azpy)(dmf)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O): C, 44.21; H, 5.25; N, 7.06. Found: C, 44.82; H, 5.19; N, 6.69%.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">The compound [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpe)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2DMF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) was prepared using a similar procedure to that used to prepare Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. A DMF solution (200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>oba (5.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and bpe (3.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was allowed to diffuse into a DMF solution (200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of Zn(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (2.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol). Colorless cubic crystals were formed within a period of one week, and these were collected by filtration under a nitrogen atmosphere because of the highly moisture sensitivity. One crystal of each compound was used in the single crystal X-ray analysis, and the residual crystals were used for other measurements. Elemental Anal. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">52</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">60</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> ([Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpe)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4DMF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O): C, 53.30; H, 5.16; N, 7.17. Found: C, 53.69; H, 4.79; N, 7.46%.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st020">Preparation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: CoCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTE (0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>NOH (25% in water, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml), DMF (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) and CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) were placed in a 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml Teflon-lined autoclave which was kept at 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days and then slowly cooled to room temperature at about 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h. Purple block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained. Elemental analysis: calculated (%) for C<ce:inf loc="post">111</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">76</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf> without the solvent molecules: C 62.11, H 3.54, N 2.61; found (%): C 64.40, H 5.96, N 2.35. The discrepancy would be due to the involved solvent molecules in the lattices. FT-IR (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3423(br), 2961(m), 2930(m), 2865(m), 1675(s), 1606(s), 1547(w), 1492(s), 1287(w), 1260(s), 1135(m), 1081(s), 840(m).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st040">Syntheses of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> </ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Synthesis of {(cation)[Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(bptca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>(solvent)}<ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> </ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). A mixture of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptca (0.082<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.121<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and two drops of concentrated HNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (63%, aq.) in distilled water (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and DMA (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was placed in a 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL screw-capped vial, heated to 105<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The pH value of mother solution is about 6. Blue block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained in 36% yield based on copper. Elemental analyses (%): C, 45.09; H, 2.79; N, 3.94. IR/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (KBr): 3422(s), 3245(m), 2934(w), 1622(s), 1384(s), 1294(m), 1270(m), 1097(w), 1018(m), 939(w), 772(m), 733(m), 694(m), 664(w), 595(w), 556(w), 487(m). {(cation)[Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(bptca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>(solvent)}<ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> </ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) was obtained by the same procedure as that for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> except that different ratio of the reactant was employed (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptca (0.082<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.060<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol)). Yield: 42% based on copper. Elemental analyses (%): C, 47.35; H, 2.96; N, 4.37. IR/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (KBr): 3426(s), 3253(m), 2804(w), 2483(w), 1610(s), 1429(s), 1369(s), 1028(m), 938(w), 848(w), 777(m), 727(s), 667(m), 596(w), 557(w), 496(m).</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">The reaction of 4,4′-bipyridine with CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·8/3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in water in 1:1 mole ratio in a sealed tube at 120°C gave <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> as pure crystalline product in 57% yield. A sample of 256 mg (1.0 mmol) CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·8/3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and 156 mg (1.0 mmol) 4,4′-bipyridine was mixed thoroughly and loaded into a thick-walled Pyrex tube. After ∼1.0 ml H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was added, the tube was frozen with liquid N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, evacuated under vacuum and sealed with a flame. The reaction was carried out at 120°C for 24 h to afford colorless single crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The product was isolated by acetone washing in 57% yield. The compound is insoluble in common organic solvents such as THF, acetone, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN or water. The single crystal X-ray structure analysis showed that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the C-centered, noncentrosymmetric space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2 (No. 5). Crystallographic data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, C<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">28</ce:inf>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, monoclinic <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2 (No. 5), <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=24.624(1), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=9.7554(5), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=13.5956(7) Å, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>=120.663(1)°, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>=2809.2(2) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=4, <ce:italic>ρ</ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">calc</ce:inf>=1.980 g cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>=1.740 mm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>=295 K, structure solution and refinement based on 5239 reflections including Friedel mates (3254 unique) with <ce:italic>I</ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">o</ce:inf>≥3.0<ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>(<ce:italic>I</ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">o</ce:inf>) converged at <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>=0.0342, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">w</ce:inf>=0.0481 and goodness-of-fit=1.85. Data were collected on a Siemens SMART diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073 Å). An empirical absorption correction based on redundant reflections was applied to the data set. The absolute configuration was unambiguously assigned based on the analysis of the Bijovot pairs and the refinement of the Flack parameter. The absence of inversion center in the structure was also confirmed by MISYM. The refinement of Flack parameter for the chosen configuration gave 0.00020(9) with 5239 reflections where <ce:italic>F</ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf>(H) and <ce:italic>F</ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf>(–H) differ by more than 0.0001. The asymmetric unit contains two Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions, two 4,4′-bipy ligands, two SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> <ce:sup loc="post"> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> anions, and three coordinate and three crystallization water molecules. The metal centers are first linked by the SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> <ce:sup loc="post"> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> anions to form the one-dimensional arrays of fused 12-membered rings containing three cadmium, three sulfur and six oxygen atoms (see <ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>). The arrays are drawn together by hydrogen bonding between the coordinate water molecules and the SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> <ce:sup loc="post"> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> anions from the adjacent net. The two SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> <ce:sup loc="post"> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> anions are split into μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>- and μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bridging ligands. Thus, Cd(1) is coordinated by a μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> <ce:sup loc="post"> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup>, a μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> <ce:sup loc="post"> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> and two <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules while the Cd(2) is linked by a μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> <ce:sup loc="post"> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup>, two different μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> <ce:sup loc="post"> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> anions and a water. The 4,4′-bipy ligands act as ‘posts’ that connect the cadmium centers to form the one-dimensional [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post"> <ce:italic>n</ce:italic> </ce:inf> <ce:sup loc="post"> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4+</ce:sup> chains. The coordination of both Cd atoms can best be described as slightly distorted octahedral with four O atoms situated in the square plane and two N atoms occupying the axial positions. <ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor> depicts the coordination environments of the two Cd atoms. Rather than being parallel, these chains run across each other from two different directions. Thus, the compound forms three-dimensional interwoven networks as shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>. The most common coordination modes of the SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> <ce:sup loc="post"> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> ion are monodentate, bidentate and μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-bridging, while μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bridging is much less frequent . The combination of both μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>- and μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bridging in the same structure is hitherto unreported. The fact that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in a noncentrosymmetric space group can perhaps be attributed to this unusual combination of the two different bridging modes for the SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> <ce:sup loc="post"> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> anion. We have noticed that the use of simple, weaker coordinating anions such as NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> <ce:sup loc="post"> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> and ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> <ce:sup loc="post"> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> results in centrosymmetric more often than noncentrosymmetric crystal packing.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Two interpenetrating coordination polymers are assembled from Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> and 4-(2-ethyl-1<ce:italic>H</ce:italic>-imidazol-1-yl)benzate.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The synthetic methods include solvothermal condition and layer diffusion.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">They display 3-fold <ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> and 4-fold <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> interpenetrating networks.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Interconvertible structural transformations between them are studied.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Long-standing interest in the area of coordination polymers (CPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) stems from their tectonic aesthetics of crystalline architectures and potential functions in fields of optical, magnetic, electronic, catalysis, chiral, and microporous crystalline materials . At this stage, design of the target materials is based upon the sophisticated selection and utilization of specific organic and inorganic building tectons . Furthermore, some accessorial reaction parameters, such as pH , solvent , anion , and additive , are also critical for the fabrication of well-defined CPs. In comparison, studies on the regulation effect of CPs and their reversible structural transformations, via tuning distinct synthetic approaches, have been rarely reported . As a continuation of our research , we will present herein two distinct Zn(II) CPs of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2-eiba)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)]<ce:inf loc="post"> <ce:italic>n</ce:italic> </ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[Zn(2-eiba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post"> <ce:italic>n</ce:italic> </ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) via solvothermal synthesis and layer diffusion method, respectively. <ce:footnote id="fn0005"> <ce:label>1</ce:label> <ce:note-para id="np0005" view="all">Synthesis of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2-eiba)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)]<ce:inf loc="post"> <ce:italic>n</ce:italic> </ce:inf> <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold>. Mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (29.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and 2-Heiba (21.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. Colorless block single crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were collected by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h (yield: 15.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg). Anal. Calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">34</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C,54.49; H,4.32; N,10.59%. Found: C, 54.68; H, 4.29; N, 10.39%. IR (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>): 3401m, 3146m, 3058m, 1617vs, 1561m, 1513m, 1466m, 1379vs, 1307w, 1254w, 1176m, 1149w, 1107w, 1053s, 1009w, 960w, 879w, 849m, 788s, 743w, 722m, 644w, 617w, 584w, 547m, 524w, 504w, 458w, 411w. Synthesis of {[Zn(2-eiba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post"> <ce:italic>n</ce:italic> </ce:inf> <ce:bold>(2)</ce:bold>. A methanol solution (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of 2-Heiba (21.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was carefully layered onto a water solution (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (29.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in a glass tube. Colorless block crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained by slow evaporation of the solvent at room temperature after three days (yield: 18.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg). Anal. Calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">28</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>Zn: C, 52.42; H, 5.13; N, 10.19%. Found: C, 52.46; H, 5.18; N, 10.11%. IR (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>): 3405b, 1632vs, 1575w, 1510m, 1462m, 1361vs, 1308m, 1251w, 1172m, 1147w, 1110w, 1053s, 1012m, 874w, 843m, 787m, 704m, 574m, 546m, 513m, 442w.</ce:note-para> </ce:footnote> Single-crystal X-ray structural analyses reveal that they display different entangled architectures, 3-fold and 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-fold types, respectively. More interestingly, interconvertible structrual transformations between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be achieved with intensive rearrangement of the overall crystalline lattice. Thermal stability and fluorescence properties of these complexes have also been studied.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Materials</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The reagents CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> <ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> <ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and nicotinic acid were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and used as received.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Preparation of the Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> <ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.43 g, 2.52 mmol) was added to a methanolic solution (25 ml) containing nicotinic acid (0.75 g, 6.09 mmol). The mixture was then heated to reflux for 6 h until some blue solid began to precipitate. The solid was filtered out, washed with diethylether (2<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>10 ml) and dried under vacuum to give a blue powder. Yield: 0.75 g (91%). UV–Vis (DMF): 438 nm (<ce:italic>ε</ce:italic>=1406.2 M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> <ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>CuN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>M</ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">w</ce:inf>=357.80), C, 44.24; H, 3.09; N, 8.60. Found: C, 43.75; H, 3.01; N, 9.08%. IR (KBr disk): 1636(m), 1560(s), 1543(s), 1508(w), 1457(m), 1384(s), 1307(w), 1191(m), 762(m), 683(m), 669(w), 651(m), 472(w). Dark blue crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained by slow diffusion of CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH into a DMF solution of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Preparation of Co(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> <ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.29 g, 1.0 mmol) was added to a CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> solution (20 ml) containing nicotinic acid (0.25 g, 2.0 mmol). The mixture was then refluxed for 48 h to afford a red solution and a red solid. The precipitate was filtered and washed with ether (3<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>10 ml) and then dried under reduced pressure to give a dark red solid. Yield: 0.28 g (92%). UV–Vis (DMF): 382 nm (<ce:italic>ε</ce:italic>=1045.8 M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> <ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>CoN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>M</ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">w</ce:inf>=303.14), C, 47.55; H, 2.66; N, 9.24. Found: C, 47.54; H, 3.03; N, 9.67%. IR (KBr disk): 1385(s), 1192(s), 1048(s), 828(m), 756(s), 698(m), 451(w). Red crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained by slow diffusion of ether into a MeOH/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O solution of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">Cobalt(II) chloride complexes were synthesized using the layering technique. A typical procedure was as follows: in a glass tube the solution of 0.040 g (0.3 mmol) <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> in 6 ml DMF (first layer), 5 ml of 1:1 DMF/methanol mixture and solution of 0.036 g (0.15 mmol) CoCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in 5 ml MeOH were layered each on the top of the other avoiding interfusion. The crystals of the product grew on walls of the tube as the solutes slowly interdiffused for the period of 7–10 days. The product consists of two complexes, crystals of which were separated manually: [Co(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2DMF (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), light-pink blocks and [Co(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>), pink prisms.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">An easy, but specific procedure was employed for crystallization of copper(II) coordination polymers. Thus, solutions of 0.110 g (0.35 mmol) CuSiF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in 2 ml water and 0.088 g (0.72 mmol) KClO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in 3 ml water were combined and precipitate of K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SiF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> was filtered off. To the resulting copper(II) chlorate solution 0.094 g (0.70 mmol) of solid <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> was added and the mixture was stored at room temperature for about 50 days that effected total dissolution of the ligand and crystallization of the complex [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>10</ce:bold>) as large deep cyan–blue blocks. The yield was 0.14 g (70%). In similar conditions, reaction of solid <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> ligand with aq. solutions of copper(II) salts afforded well-crystalline products: [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), light-green and [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), green–blue. This procedure, under presence of water soluble aromatics, also allows the preparation of inclusion compounds, cf. [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O·C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>), blue prisms.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">Heating a solution of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CMe)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′ (3:1:3) in DMF at 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in a sealed tube for 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, followed by slow cooling down to ambient temperature, gave dark green crystals of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post"> <ce:italic>n</ce:italic> </ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) directly from the reaction solution; the yield was ca. 50% . With the identity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> established by crystallography , a convenient synthesis of the pure material was sought under alternative reaction conditions. Thus, the reaction of three equivalents of CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with two equivalents of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′, in the presence of four equivalents of LiOH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, in DMF and layering of Et<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1:1 v/v) onto the resulting olive green solution gave dark green crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; the yield is ∼70%.</ce:para>

<ce:simple-para id="sp0080" view="all">Synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: The mixture of CoSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) or Ni(Ac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Htpba (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), (NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), distilled water (9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and DMF (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) were stirred about 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min in air, then transferred and sealed in a 17<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which were heated at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h under autogenous pressure. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h, purple block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and green block crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained, washed with distilled water several times, and dried at ambient temperature. We speculate that the DMF and/or (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH may act as bases during the preparation procedures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. For compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, yield: 51% based on tpba. Found: C, 36.24; H, 3.21; Co, 7.35; Mo, 24.12; N, 7.09%. For compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, yield: 55% based on tpba. <ce:simple-para id="sp0055" view="all">Preparation of [H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]⋅[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(ad)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>4DMF: A mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> <ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L (15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.025<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), adenine (8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.06<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was added in a mixture solution of DMF (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL). Then 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL HNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was added in the mixture. The obtain mixture was sealed into a 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 135<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for three days. The as-synthesized samples can be obtained after filtration at room temperature. Finally, the yellow block-shaped crystals were washed with fresh DMF and dried in air. Yield: 52.9% (based on the H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L). <ce:section-title>Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all"> <ce:display> <ce:e-component> <ce:label>Supplementary material</ce:label> <ce:caption> <ce:simple-para view="all">Crystallographic data.</ce:simple-para> </ce:caption> <ce:link locator="mmc1"></ce:link> </ce:e-component> </ce:display> </ce:para><ce:simple-para view="all">The phosphonic acid with formula (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)-NC<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>N-(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>), was prepared according to Moedritzer Irani method. The crude product was dissolved in THF to obtain a white precipitate, that was triturated (stirred) overnight, the white solid was then filtered, washed with fresh THF and oven dried to yield the title compound (86%). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was obtained under solvothermal conditions by mixing 0.404<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g of Ce(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) with 0.328<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g of bispiperidine diphosphonic acid (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml of distilled water and the mixture was placed in closed Teflon bottle and maintained at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for two days. A pale-yellow powder precipitate was recovered in 86% yield.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title id="st035">Synthesis of Ag(L)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Ligand L (19.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–MeCN (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL, 1:1, v/v) in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL vial, to which an acetonitrile solution of AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (33.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was added upon stirring at room temperature. The resulting solution was allowed to stir for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min and then filtered. Slow evaporation of the filtrate over 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days gave colorless crystals, which were suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The product was collected by decanting the solvent and then washed with diethyl ether, and dried in the air. Yield: 30.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg (84% based on L). Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (30.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), tpt (15.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta (16.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg,0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was mixed in 14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL DMF in a vial. The vial was sealed and allowed to stand at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. As the reaction progresses, light yellow rod shape crystal formed. Homogeneous crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air (yield: 35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg). Anal. found: C, 50.83; H, 4.19; N, 13.52%.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In a typical procedure pytac (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), cobalt nitrate or cadmium iodide (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and ammonium vanadate (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), were placed in a 23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined autoclave with 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL water. The autoclave was subsequently sealed and heated to 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min and held at that temperature for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. At the end of this period, the autoclave was cooled to 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min and held at that temperature for 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h before cooling to room temperature at the same rate. Cobalt nitrate and pytac were utilized for the synthesis of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. An irregular orange crystal fragment was cleaved from a multi-crystalline mass and used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis. Cobalt nitrate, ammonium vanadate, and pytac were used in the synthesis of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. An irregular, orange-red crystal was used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis. Cadmium iodide and pytac were used to synthesize complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. A yellow bar-shaped crystal was used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st040">Synthesis of the catalyst</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">A mixture of (NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.124<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.052<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), 4,4′-bipy (0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.047<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), 1,10-phenanthroline (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.036<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), KF (0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.017<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) was stirred for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min in air. The starting pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 5.5 by the addition of diluted ethylenediamine solution followed by transferring it to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and keeping it at 165<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. After slow cooling to room temperature, the resulting product containing 0.162<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g of a mixture of blue (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and yellow ([Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> <ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>Cl(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>(1,10-phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]) (4,4′-bipy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-bipyridine and 1,10-phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,10-phenanthroline) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) crystals, was filtered off, washed with distilled water and dried in air.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sect0045">Synthesis of [Zn(L)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(4,4′-bpy)]·2(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (1)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">A solution of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> <ce:bold>·</ce:bold>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> (0.0145<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and a solution of 4,4′-bpy (0.0096<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL)were added with stirring to a solution of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L (0.0104<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.025<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in DMF (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), then 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was added to this mixture solution. After the mixture solution was stirred for 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min, 2 drops of 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L HNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> solution was added to this reaction solution, and then the reaction mixture solution were stirred for another 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min. The colorless solution had been obtained and then sealed in a 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL sealing glass vessel. The vessel was heated to 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and held at that temperature for 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, then slowly cooling to room temperature, block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for single crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained by filtration and dried at air. yield:80%. Anal. Caled.(%): C 52.09, H 4.08, N 6.02. Found (%): C 52.62, H 4.17, N 5.94. EDX El. AN. (wt%): Zn 11.41, O 26.07, C 54.95, N 7.57. (at%): Zn 2.52, O 23.55, C 66.12, N 7.81. <ce:section-title id="sectitle0050">Synthesis of complexes <ce:bold>1∼3</ce:bold> </ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0055">Preparation of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)(1,4-bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·2DMF (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">A mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> (16.6 mg, 0.05 mmol), 1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) was put in a reaction vessel (10 ml) and DMF (3 ml) was added to it, then sealed, with ultrasonic processing for 30 min the solid completely dissolved in DMF giving a clear solution. The reaction solution was heated at 70 °C for five days then cooled to room temperature and filtered, after the solid was washed with DMF and dried to obtain many yellow petals crystals (ca. 51.2% yield based on <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>). <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The magnetic property of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was investigated over the temperature range of 2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at an applied field of 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe ( <ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>). At 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> value of 4.402<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (5.934 μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>) is much higher than the spin-only value of 1.875<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (3.873 μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>) expected for one isolated Co(II) ions (S<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3/2, g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.0) (a), which can be ascribed to the orbital contribution to the magnetic moment of Co(II) centers . Upon cooling, the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> value decreases monotonically and reaches a value of 2.043<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, which can be attributed to spin-orbit coupling and/or crystal field effect and/or zero-field splitting (ZFS) . The Curie-Weiss fitting of 1/<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> in the temperature range of 36–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K gives a good result with C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4.460<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>47.289<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">In the present work, we report the syntheses and characteristics of two microporous interpenetrated frameworks, [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][Co(tpba)(Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][Ni(tpba)(Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (tpba<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-([4.2′:6′,4′′-terpyridin]-4′-yl)benzoic acid), which are constructed from metal–organic layers pillared by the [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions. Topologically, the overall structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be simplified as a (3,5)-connected twofold interpenetrated <ce:bold>hms</ce:bold> net with the point symbol of (6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">9</ce:sup>.8) . The crystal structure, topological analysis and magnetic property of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> will be represented and discussed in this paper.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The engineering of porous coordination polymers, also known as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), tends to be the most rapidly investigated area not only due to their intriguing architectures but also being potential functional materials probably in diverse areas . Indeed, the pore apertures of MOFs determine the size of the guest molecules, which embodies those functional features as a carrier. In general, the construction of porous structural topologies immensely depends on the organic ligands and the coordination geometry of central metal ions . One successful strategy for making large porous MOFs and avoiding appearance of interpenetration is to construct a framework by the “short axis – long axis” mode . The design solution can maintain a short axis with the long organic links inclined to that axis. The short axis by metal–oxygen bonds is the distance between the long organic links of ligand skeleton along that axis joining the secondary building units (SBUs), and effectively eliminates the possibility of framework interpenetration. Conceptually, the main efforts are centered around the choice of suitable organic multicarboxylate ligands . Among various multicarboxylate ligands, asymmetrical carboxylate ligands have been reported rarely in the fabrication of MOFs . Those can be utilized to form large porous MOFs because of their asymmetrical nature in favor of the short axis – long axis arrangement, in which the organic carbon backbone acts as the longer linkage with the asymmetrical carboxyls leaning against the backbone as the short rods . Meanwhile, the twisted conformations of asymmetrical carboxyl ligands benefit the generation of polynuclear metal clusters for addressing that strategy .</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Two adjacent Cu1 ions are linked by four bidentate bridging carboxylate groups to afford a paddle-wheel Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> subunit with the Cu–Cu distance of 2.6391(18)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, being shorter than that of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (b). Due to the different coordination environment of Cu atoms, the respective paddle-wheel units in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, also display some differences, which each bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> <ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> connects only one paddle-wheel cluster and the cation of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> does two paddle-wheel clusters. The Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> fragment gets ulteriorly incorporation with four neighboring paddle-wheel clusters <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> two bidentate bridging carboxylate groups of isophthalate to give a single Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> paddle-wheel supporting grid structure. These 2D layers are linked in the third direction by folded mononuclear Cu(bptc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units, to form a 3D nanoporous framework (c). Similar to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the framework accommodates infinite open 1D quadrate channels with 11.20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å caliber (Cu…Cu distance). Meanwhile, the closely arrangement of the components on the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp> <ce:italic>×</ce:italic> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp> <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> or <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp> <ce:italic>×</ce:italic> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp> <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> plane suggests the noninterpenetrating features of the final framework (). The potential solvent-accessible volume of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is 2129.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, which corresponds to 42.7% of unit cell volume 4991.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> according to the <ce:small-caps>platon</ce:small-caps> calculations . From the viewpoint of the network topology, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> possesses 3D (4,4)-connected binodal frameworks with {4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>} PtS-type topology, by considering each mononuclear Cu(bptca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and paddle-wheel Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> clusters as 4-connected nodes (d).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st040">TG measurement</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Thermal gravimetric (TG) curves of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits two-step weight loss below 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C ( <ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). The weight loss from room temperature to about 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be assigned to the release of all coordinated water, DMF molecules and lattice solvent molecules. The second weight loss from 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be attributed to the decomposition of the compound, which is indicated by an exothermal peak at 413<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in the DSC curve. The residue value is of 20% due to the formation of CoO. Later, the weight increases a little with the increasing temperature, which might be caused by the oxidation of the CoO intermediate product.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The adsorption of water vapor by porous solids is important for many applications, such as dehumidification, thermal batteries, and requiring capture and release of water. More recently, MOFs have been demonstrated to be promising water vapor adsorption materials . Herein, we further show that high and steep water vapor uptake at low relative pressure can be achieved by our interpenetrated Cd-NDC MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The water vapor adsorption isotherm of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is shown in b. Notably, the maximum water uptake at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K reaches 281<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> under <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>P</ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.95 (where <ce:italic>P</ce:italic> <ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> is the vapor pressure at saturation). The maximum water uptake of MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is comparable to the values of Basolite A100 and another cadmium(II) MOF reported by D. F. Li, which are 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and 249<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, respectively, Significantly, this value is much higher than a lot of MOF material, including CAU-10 functionalised by –NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and –OCH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> groups , DUT-84 (Zr) , and Fe-MOFs reported by Tapas Kumar Maji . To the best of our knowledge, the water vapor adsorption capacity of MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K outperforms all previously reported interpenetrated MOFs.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The contemporary interest in the chemistry of polyoxometallates (POMs) stems from not only their potential applications in fields as diverse as catalysis, medicine, molecular magnetism and material science but also their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies. The incorporation of metal–organic moieties into inorganic oxide clusters provides a powerful method for structural modification and synthesis of novel metallorganic–inorganic hybrid materials that combine different characteristics of the components to obtain unusual structures or properties. Oxovanadium compounds have provided a long-standing fascination for chemists due to their potential applications and their intriguing variety of topologies .</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">Data were collected with Mo K<ce:italic>a</ce:italic> radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and on a Siemens SMART CCD diffractometer for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. With <ce:small-caps>shelxtl</ce:small-caps> program, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was solved with heavy-atom method and compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with direct methods. Then both were refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques. The non-hydrogen atoms for both were assigned anisotropic displacement parameters in the refinement. For compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the hydrogen atoms were obtained from difference Fourier map, and for compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the hydrogen atoms were treated with a riding model except ones on N atoms being obtained from difference Fourier map. The structures were then refined on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic> <ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps>-97. Basic information pertaining to the crystal parameters and structure refinement of the title compounds is summarized in <ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in <ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">The 3-D network compounds [NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pip)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pip)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) have been reported, which constructed from 1-D zigzag NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chains and 1-D merlon-like CuI double chains bridged by pip molecules, respectively.
